Though it gives us an excuse to nick some Richard Knights at Liberum on Chinese iron ore demand.

BE11:14am

Chinese port stocks of iron ore have fallen by c.30mt over the past three months at the same time as prices have added c.$30/t, closing last night at close to cycle highs at $110/t.

Grouchmonkey @soundbuy short squeeze? Scapa has been under the cosh for a while
11:15 am
BE11:15am

Wait, no, that's old. Ignore me. Try this one, from Ben Davis at Liberum.

BE11:16am

We are downgrading BHP, Anglo American and Rio Tinto to HOLD with a number of recent data points indicating the top may now be in for iron ore. In particular, steel inventories at traders have been unseasonally restocking, iron ore port inventory declines have stalled (actually built last week), spot steel mill profitability in China has now fallen to break-even levels and supply from scrap steel and domestic iron ore appear to have accelerated.

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 2,188, down 73 (-3.23%), High: 2,240, Low: 2,181, Volume: 1.52m
GBKrona @soundbuy - scapa looks like one big holder trying to average down their historical cost... huge spread, brokers making a killing here
11:16 am
BE11:16am

We still see the seaborne market in deficit as finished steel apparent consumption remains strong, but a continuation of the current supply growth trends in conjunction with softer end-demand could see this deficit disappear sooner than expected. A slowdown in housing construction data which has continued to run well ahead of sales would be the key SELL signal, with steel output growth this year disproportionately geared towards rebar.

Even though we see limited downside (and even upside risk) in copper and aluminium here as credit growth accelerates further, the scale of iron ore’s contribution to sector earnings, even when a low multiple is applied, means stagnant or weaker prices will make it difficult for these stocks to rally. Given the risks outlined, we are downgrading our H2 iron ore estimate from $110/t to $100/t. Our price targets for Anglo (£22/shr) and BHP (£20/shr) remain unchanged, but we downgrade our Rio Tinto price target to £45/shr (from £55/shr) bringing its P/NPV multiple back to 1.5x (from 1.7x), in line with the rest of the sector.

Soundbuy @Grouchmonkey - noted...........had wondered if any ConvaTec news.........
marktime There should be an ambient working temperature above which we all get the day off
BE11:17am

Soundbuy @GB - yep, possibly
red @marktimei thought most folks just sit on FB all day at work anyway
GBKrona @soundbuy - did you see the legal claims Scapa posted details online? - only filed this month, so bit early for news
PBateman morning morning

11:18 am
BE11:18am

After Rio Tinto’s strong performance YTD (+30% for both Plc and Ltd), we now focus on our expectation that iron ore pricing is approaching a turning point with momentum in China port inventory drawdowns slowing and supply continuing to recover. This factor, combined with a lack of meaningful valuation support, leads us to downgrade Rio Tinto to Underperform (from Neutral). We make small changes to target price (UK down ~1% to £43.0/sh (from £43.4/sh); Australian listing down to A$92/sh (from A$95/sh)) to bring it back in line with our NPV methodology. On an EV/EBITDA basis (targeting ~4x), we believe the stock is pricing in a 2020 iron ore price of ~US$105/t versus our forecast of US$85/t.

marktime Yes @red I was including the idlers too
BE11:18am

Commodity price turning points are vital: Despite the high likelihood of further consensus earnings upgrades as the market factors in iron ore prices which continue to be ahead of estimates, we feel that history shows that, if commodity pricing momentum has already turned, then these earnings moves are lagging indicators of share-price performance.
■ Still a high quality business: Rio Tinto remains a high quality business (albeit with some recent operational challenges in iron ore and copper which need to be closely watched); however, a lack of near-term growth makes it difficult for the company to offset commodity price-driven earnings decline; we see EBITDA falling ~17% over the next 2 years.

Sultan of swaps hi folks

(@marktime: right click and open in new tab works. We try and make the user experience as difficult as possible so you end up convincing yourselves it's all somehow worth it.)

11:20 am
undefined
BE11:21am

While on miners and/or sellside ......

Petra Diamonds Ltd (PDL:LSE): Last: 13.37, down 1.98 (-12.90%), High: 15.08, Low: 13.00, Volume: 12.29m
GBKrona @Soundbuy - much too early - and Convatec hardly flush with cash
Tom Dalgleish A logical approach to iron ore demand would have it constant throught the year but it never is
11:22 am
BE11:22am

Berenberg's noticed it doesn't have enough money.

BE11:22am

We upgraded Petra Diamonds in April on the thesis that deleveraging
would drive an equity re-rating. While this theme played out for a time,
Petra’s Q4 interim management statement (IMS) and FY 2020E guidance
highlighted that this deleveraging would be slower than we had
anticipated. Further, the impact of reduced diamond price estimates
(driven by weak diamond markets) materially reduce our NAV and our
cash flow projections; this both increases the risk of a further equity
financing as Petra moves towards the maturity of its USD650m bond in
May 2022, and heightens our concern about its ability to repay its
refinanced debt over the current life of mine to 2030. In our view, this
leaves little near-term upside for shareholders, and feel that for now, Petra
is working for the banks, with equity holders forced to take a backseat
and/or assist in a refinancing. We downgrade the stock to Sell on mediumterm funding concerns with a GBp8 price target, implying 48% downside.

BE11:22am

So ....... cash call required.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Petra has set a target of free cash flow
generation between FY 2020E and FY 2022E of USD150m-200m. While we
think that there is likely a dose of conservatism in these numbers, we
believe that there is optimism here too, including a 7% rand devaluation
which contributes USD45m to the target. We forecast adjusted FCF
generation of USD135m over FY 2020E-22E, and think that this leaves
Petra with the need to refinance cUSD475m of forecast debt when it falls
due. To us, this is still too much debt considering our forecast cash flow
generation. Based on a life of mine to 2030, coupled with an increase in
capex from FY 2023E as deferred capex is incurred, we do not think that
Petra’s operations will generate enough cash to repay the refinanced debt
principal in full, and thus we think that the likelihood of an equity raise (as
part of the debt refinancing) has increased. The issue for equity holders is
that, based on a 2030 life of mine for most mines, cash flow returns after
debt is repaid are not compelling (we calculate that, based on a USD150m
equity raise, equity holders would just make their money back).

(@Grouchmonkey: last 16 weeks.)

Forester To be fair to Marstons, unlike GK they have kept their local ales intact and distinct.
11:34 am
BE11:34am

Here's Liberum to summarise.

BE11:34am

Trading for the 42 weeks to 20 July has weakened with LFL sales across the managed and franchised business increasing by +0.5%. LFL sales in the Destination and Premium pub division was +0.1%, whilst it was 1.1% in the more wet-led Taverns business.

Trading over the last 16 weeks has been challenging with total managed and franchised LFL sales falling by -2.3%, (-1.7% D&P and -3.5% Taverns). This is understandably due to the less favourable weather over the last few months compared to last year, and the boost in last year’s trading from the Men’s World Cup, however we would have expected a better D&P performance which should have been less exposed to these comparatives (see chart below). In our view, D&P has underperformed that market with Coffer Peach Business Tracker for April to June showing Pub LFL sales of -0.3% and Restaurant LFL sales of +2.8%.

Beer volumes remain flat compared to last year as Marston’s Beer Company continues to outperform the market; however lager sales (particularly Estrella Damm) in the off-trade have been relatively weaker, which has hampering overall Q3 volume performance.

BE11:35am

Expansion deferred, debt reduction prioritised

In January the company made clear its intention to reduce net debt by £200m to £1.2bn by FY23E. Progress has been made so far this year via targeting asset disposals, re-profiling its interest swaps and reducing capex spend across the business. The company has announced today that it intends to accelerate its debt reduction strategy by deferring £70m of the new-build investment that had been planned over the next three year. £20-30m will be invested into organic growth at higher returns, with the remaining £40-50m cash flow used to offset net debt.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Potential step up in M&A

Marston’s is targeting c£40-45m pa of disposals, largely from its tenanted estate, as it streamlines the business. We believe the read-across from Stonegate’s recent bid for Ei Group (4.3% premium to tangible NAV and 9.7 forward EV/EBITDA) is positive of this valuation and could lead to a step up in the pace of industry M&A transactions. Additionally, we note recent newspaper reports that Marston’s has appointed advisers to explore the sale of its c20 Pitcher & Piano chain with an estimated value of c£40m.

Forester @soundbuy I used to be a Bank's Mild fan...good session stuff for impoverished students
Soundbuy Aye, still the old Wolverhampton site......
BE11:35am

Earnings adjustment

The weakness in trading over the last 16 weeks was more considerable than we had anticipated, leading us to take a more cautious view on Q4 outlook. Hence we are reducing our LFL expectations from 2.0% to 0.5%, which given the reduction in tax rate to 16.0%, results in EPS cut of 2.0% for FY19E. Additionally, we have reflected the revised capex guidance and deferral of expansion which results in 3.5% cut for FY20E and 4.1% cut for FY21E. Importantly, the dividend is unaffected.

Sultan of swaps tough time for pubs, regulator, now the weather

BE11:36am

Dividend unaffected when management's scrapped expansion and is flogging stuff to get debt under control while earnings deteriorate. Righty ho.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

A difficult Q3 trading should not overshadow Marston’s high-quality freehold pub estate, which has delivered positive long term LFLs, and its market leading beer business. Progress on deleveraging is promising and will continue to strengthen the business. Marston’s stock is trading on CY20E EV/EBITDA of 8.9x and PE of 7.5x, FCF Yield of 7.6% and Dividend yield of 6.9%, and 25% discount to book NAV.

BE11:37am

Peel Hunt .....

BE11:37am

Managed LFL sales fell by 2% and brewing volumes were down
5% in Q3 (16 weeks). Both figures were slightly worse than we
expected, hence we are downgrading our forecasts by 3%, which
is greater than what we predicted in our preview. The good news
is that debt reduction plans are being increased with the new
build programme taking a three-year breather. After recent
strength, we are moving our recommendation from Add to Hold.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

We forecast net debt to fall to c£1.31bn, from £1.4bn, between 2020 and
2021E, reducing net debt/EBITDA from 6.2x to 5.7x, whilst maintaining a
dividend that currently yields 6%. The recent share price increase partly
reflected the 11x EV/EBITDA that Stonegate paid for Ei Group, but this is
likely to leave Stonegate as a seller, not a buyer, of pub assets, and those
with the lowest leverage will be best placed to exploit this opportunity.

BE11:38am

You get the idea.

undefined

11:41 am

BE11:42am

Goldman can summarise:

11:42 am
BE11:43am

Aston Martin profit warned this morning as it took down volume expectations to 6.3k-6.5k units (from 7.1k-7.3k units) and also adjusted FY19 EBITDA and EBIT margin guidance. Comparing the new guidance to our own expectations, deliveries at the mid-point are c.5% lower than what we have forecast while we estimate that implied EBITDA (based off the new margin guide of 20% vs. GSe 23%) now sits at closer to c.£230 mn, 16% below our £277 mn. As a result and despite revised capex guidance of around £300mn for 2019 (GSe: £330 mn), we believe it will be challenging for Aston Martin to produce positive FCF.

BE11:43am

But does it matter?

red aml warns. wow what a surprise. gone bust as many times as i have fingers on my hands
BE11:45am

While we maintained our Buy rating on Aston Martin in our recent note, Life of Luxury, we highlighted the risk to 2019E which has now unfolded and, as outlined above, has proven worse than our own expectations. Prior to today’s warning, our 2019 EBITDA was 5% below consensus. This was driven by our below-consensus (and below-guidance) expectations for volumes (GSe: 6.8k units vs. consensus 7.1k units). To get to our volume number, we had assumed seasonality for the existing models in line with history leading to 6,200 units. In addition, we saw the opportunity for c.600 sales from new models/specials. We wait to see which part of these assumptions has proven too optimistic, although we believe the “specials” should be reasonably well protected.

Sultan of swaps I'm just wondering how as a luxury car maker you can succeed when you outsource motors to AMG ... Designed in the UK, made in Germany... Come on...
Excel Developer Automobiles stocks interesting t the moment. Nissan soon to report a 90% profit fall allegedly,
11:46 am
BE11:46am

The Aston Martin buy case was not driven by 2019 but instead a longer-term story, largely hinging on the successful launch of the DBX next year and subsequent models. Our volume/EBIT/EPS are comfortably ahead of consensus for 2020/21. We wait for further insight from the company on the drivers of this year’s lower shipments and the implications for outer years.
Aston Martin is a medium-term story and its future is unlikely to be defined by 2019’s performance. Nevertheless, concerns around operating risk (not just in the plants but in the sales and distribution network) as well as questions on Aston’s ability to sustain volumes on vehicles that are more than 12 months old are all areas of concern for investors. Today’s profit warning will add to these concerns. We believe the market will be focused on any commentary from management addressing the operating risk and sustainability of volume questions in more detail.

BE11:55am

High Yield bonds issued by single asset mining development companies in recent history have been fairly rare, as illustrated by Fitch using Iowa Fertilizer Company (IFC) as the only comp in its public rating document. IFC's only similarity to Sirius is that it sells its end product to farmers - it isn't a project developer and it doesn't operate a mine.

However, there are a couple of recent examples in the mining industry, more specifically the lithium industry, where development projects have issued bonds into the high yield market, namely Nemaska Lithium and Pilbara Minerals.

Excel Developer I suppose today is Theresa Mays's final PMQ.
cracklenpop @Grouchmonkey Oh no, not Liz Truss...
Grouchmonkey @CS1 a reluctant remainer, yes.
Sultan of swaps LVMH tonight, street @ 10.2% org growth, but whisper is 16%..
11:56 am
BE11:56am

BE11:56am

In the bond offering document Sirius models an anticipated interest rate on the initial bond of 12%, followed by 10% for subsequent offerings once the RCF has been triggered. Relative to the Pilbara and Namaska bonds this appears to be a conservative approach and we think there are a number of reasons why Sirius could secure superior terms to those offerings (12% and 11.25%):

Neither of the Pilbara or Nemaska bonds received a public rating ahead of issue, Sirius has a B/B- rating from Fitch/S&P.
Both bonds were issued with US rates rising and the Fed in a more hawkish mindset.
Sirius has already made significant progress with construction, which commenced in Q4'16.
Technical risks in production are arguably considerably lower given very simple processing route.
Project costing and and feasibility work has been done to a project finance spec, with some risk passed on to contractors.
Of the two lithium industry bonds clearly the Nemaska bond has performed worse (trading at 96.6 currently) after the company announced in February this year its capex estimate for the project had increased by 34% and it would require a further $283m to complete the project.

Compared to Nemaska we think the risk of a capex increase that results in an incremental funding requirement is low. Of the remaining $2.7bn of capital left to be spent, only $757m is subject to variable pricing - primarily labour and owners costs. The $524m contingency reflects c.70% headroom on this number. Over and above this, the RCF has a further $1bn of available liquidity which will become available in $200m increments as each additional $500m is drawn and then offset with another HY bond. Hence, under the planned base case scenario, Sirius will have a contingency of $1,524m on $757m of variable costs.

A. M. @MrTicker: actually, perhaps, in future, unconnected cars would get a bit of a boost, a privacy premium.
BE11:57am

A reminder that Sirius needs to complete the $500m bond to unlock the $2.5bn revolver from Caz.

Terrestrial's not dead! Mass market advertising still has a place in a world where you pay an Youtube influencer to unbox your product and film it in an hour-long video watched exclusively by bots.

1966AndAllThat Think sweet spot for classics is the cars from a collector's childhood...like Elvis collectables they will probably decline in price as their children sell them off. For me the classic car probably a Capri.
BE12:02pm

In truth the figures are pretty mixed but the expectation was for guidance to be on the cautious side.

red @1966AndAllThat👍
12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Turns out management's a tad more optimistic. Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE12:02pm

H1 revenues are down 7% to £1476m (MSe £1486m). EBITA is down 13% at £327m (MSe £296m) and net eps are down 13% at 6.2p (MSe 5.4p) with the dividend flat at 2.6p.Broadcast revenues were £10m better than expected and the schedule cost £19m lower, The schedule cost is phasing. ITV has reiterated its £1.1bn spend for the year. This drove the c£20m beat in Broadcast. Studios EBITA also beat by £11m although the FY outlook is in line with expectations. (i) H1 advertising was down 5% (MSe - 6%): Total ITV advertising declined 7% in Q1 2019. ITV had predicted April up 8%, May -2% and June down 20%. In the end April was up 8%, May down 3% and June down 11 % with June much better than expected.Looking forward ITV has July down 5%, August up 2% and September at flat to up 5%. This implies that Q3 will be in the range of -1% to +1%. We had -5% in July, -2% in August and flat for September bringing Q3 to -2% and 9m to -5%. ITV thinks that it will be at around -3% after 9 months. We are at -3.9% for the year. A one point difference in NAR is worth c£15m.ITV total viewing is down 5% yoy.(ii) ITV Studios revenue was down 6% at £758m (MSe £765m). Studios deliveries are H2 weighted. Q1 organic revenue growth was just 1%. Our forecast of £765m implied c-10% organic in Q2 to bring H1 to -5%. ITV though has repeated that Studios for the full year will deliver at least 5% revenue growth at a 14% to 16% margin, with £130m more revenue for the full year secured at this point than last year; andITV has identified a further £5m of cost savings in 2019 and £15m over 2020 to 2022, in addition to £35m to £40m announced previouslyAt the EBITA level ITV is absorbing initial costs from the £25m investment plan in 2019. The bulk of Britbox losses (£25m/£40m 2019/20) will be felt in H2. Only £3m was incurred in H1. ITV will not be giving any further financial update today on Britbox.Consensus likely to edge up: We are below consensus at -3.9% advertising for the year and an EBITA number of £648m. The market consensus is at c-2% to-3% for advertising. Each point of NAR is worth c£15m to EBITA and there are £5m of incremental cost saves. Mechanically a shift to -3% would raise our EBITA number £15-20m.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Conclusion

H1 results were below on revenues but ahead on profit owing to phasing of costs, company is re-iterating all FY19E targets but Q3 advertising guidance of -1% to +1% is much better than our recent media buyers’ check of -3% to -4% (online advertising should be why media buyers are less accurate than in the past). On this basis and following recent share price weakness, we would expect a bit of a relief rally today.

H1 results

H1 revenues declined 7.4% to £1,476m, 2% below Barclays and 4% below ZoneFinance consensus. ITV total advertising revenues declined 4.6% to £849m, 1% ahead of Barclays and 2% ahead of consensus forecasts. Overall Broadcast & Online revenues declined 5.3% to £989m, in line with Barclays and consensus, and ITV Studios revenues declined 11.2% to £487m, 5% below Barclays and 3% below consensus. H1 EBITA declined 12.8% to £327m, 5% ahead of Barclays and 10% ahead of consensus, led by beats on both Broadcasting EBITA at £211m, 6% ahead of Barclays and 12% ahead of consensus, and Content (ITV Studios) EBITA at £116m, 3% ahead of Barclays and 5% ahead of consensus.

Headline pre-tax profit declined 15% to £301m, 4% ahead of Barclays and consensus forecasts. Headline net income declined 13% to £248m, 6% ahead of Barclays, resulting in headline diluted EPS of 6.2p, 7% ahead of Barclays and 8% ahead of consensus.

CS1 Austin Healey 3000
BE12:03pm

Q3 advertising

Interim statement reads “Economic and political uncertainty continues to impact the demand for advertising as we expected, with total advertising forecast to be in a range of -1% to +1% in Q3” and later “Total advertising is forecast to be in a range of -1% to +1% in Q3, with July down 5%, August up 2% and September flat to up 5%.”

This is better than expected with our recent media buyers’ check indicating Q3 down 3-4% (July down 12%, August down 3% and September up 2%). It could be that the inclusion of online into ITV figures is making media buyers’ forecast less reliable than in the past.

Other items

ITV unveiled a further £30m of cost cutting by 2022E (“We continue to deliver strongly on our cost savings where we are targeting, in addition to the original £35m to £40m, a further £5m this year and £15m between 2020 to 2022, totalling £55m to £60m over 2019 to 2022”)

Online advertising up 18% in 1H19A (we forecast 22.5% for FY19E) with online viewing up 13%

The end of the retransmission hope trade (“Other revenue includes revenue from platforms, such as Sky and Virgin, and third-party commissions, e.g. for services we provide to STV. This is down 13% year-on-year due to the closure of Encore at the end of April 2018 and lower commission from STV which ITV receives for selling STV’s national advertising, which corresponds with the decline in spot advertising revenue during the period.”)

1H figures are roughly in line at the sales line, but much better in profit terms due to phasing. 3Q ITV ad guidance looks slightly worse than we hoped. Shares remain intriguing to us, but a tough call; relatively cheap on a P/E of 9x and FCF/div yield at 7%/8% given Brexit uncertainty, but more importantly, mid-term structural fears over streaming competition. SOTP/multiples-based PT reduces to 120p (150p before) assuming a lower TV multiple (now 7x), implying Add retained. If we attribute a low newspaper multiple to estimated pure broadcast profit (3.5x), this with would imply a SOTP value at 92p.

A: Against low expectations going into the results, Croda 1H19 delivered an organic decline of 1% against our estimate of growth of 2.0% in H1 (there was no detailed consensus available), with the key Personal Care business -3.6%, well below worst expectations, but Life Sciences well ahead. Sales for 1H19 overall missed cons. by 1%. EBIT was £179.4m, +0.5% higher YoY, but 3% below cons of £184m, 4% below UBS. EBIT margin was 25.1% above our estimate of 24.8%, but down 30bps YoY and well below cons of 25.4% (flat YoY). EPS were 97.9p, -2% YoY, 2% below cons of 100p. The interim dividend was +3.9% YoY, ahead of the EPS decline of -2%. FCF (pre-acquisitions) was +40%, helped by lower capex and lower working capital

12:10 pm
BE12:10pm

What are the most noteworthy areas in the results?A: Personal Care organic for 1H was -3.6% (UBSe +2%), a significant deceleration on the growth of 4.1% of 2H18, but against comps which are 110 bps tougher. EBIT margin lost 80 bps YoY (UBS -170bps). Life Sciences organic sales, more encouragingly, delivered 13% against our own estimate of 6% and margins fell by only 70 bps (UBSe -190 bps) despite dilution from the Plant Impact and Brenntag Biosector acquisitions. The Perf Tech division deteriorated sequentially, which will not be a surprise to investors, given data from the auto and coatings industries; organic sales were -6% (UBSe 0%). FX provided a boost to sales of +2.8% (UBSe +3.7%)

BE12:10pm

Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?A: Yes. Management has guided to only a "slight improvement in 2H against the prior year comparator". Currently cons PBT is around £175m for 2H19 and last year's base was £157m so this suggests a cons revision of -7-8% depending on the definition of "slight", which overall would mean a FY19 revision of c5%. This would mean a broadly flat year against current UBSe +5.4% and cons. +5%. For context, 2018 delivered 6% growth and 9% growth ex-FX.

Croda had set a weak tone going into the quarter but H1 earnings nevertheless came in below expectations. A 2% pre-tax profit miss was driven by lower sales growth. The company expects a slight improvement in performance in the second half of the year. This is an arguably low hurdle to jump as 2H18 was very soft and compares to consensus at +9% PTP in 2H19 yoy. If 'slight' means low single digit, which will be a discussion point at the analyst meeting at 9am UK time, this implies ~4% downgrade to FY earnings.

12:12 pm
BE12:13pm

Croda 1H PBT came in at £171m vs company consensus of £174m, the principal negative feature being the Personal Care division where constant currency revenues and EBIT declined 3.6% and 4.6% respectively compared to an expectation at the beginning of the year of about +5%. The guidance is for a slightly better H2 performance than a year ago when £171m PBT was recorded which suggests they expect to do better than low 330s whilst consenus is low 340s now. The weak PC result is blamed on weaker US and Asia consumer confidence following the trade war and the China clampdown on cross selling (Daigou). Rival Ashland published disappointing 2Q earnings lately blamed on a weaker US but F&F co Givaudan reported no such issues though F&F is a different area and its personal care business is Eurocentric where conditions seem better. Today's results will raise concerns that this is more than a cyclical blip.
